articles.title: Introduction to CIFRIS23 ACTA
Cryptography and its Applications in the Italian Scenario
La visione di De Cifris: partnership con le aziende leader
Introduction to the Scientific Session
Keynote: MPC in the head for isomorphisms and group action
articles.abstract:
In this talk, we show how to design identification protocols and signature schemes from group actions using the MPC-in-the-head paradigm.
We prove the security of the given identification schemes and rely on the Fiat-Shamir transformation to turn them into signatures.
We also establish a parallel with the technique used for the MPC-in-the-head approach and the seed tree method that has been recently used in some signature and ring signatures algorithms based on group action problems.

Introduction to CBDCs Workshop
Crypto assets' value and investor protection
What consensus mechanism will be used for Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs)?
CBDCs: A new generation of digital cash
articles.abstract: Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs) are the next key innovation in money. They are neither digital private money, like the one of banks or credit cards, nor a cryptocurrency. Still a CBDC is a direct liability to the central bank, aiming to replicate desirable properties of cash. Their design and adoption are key considerations, significantly impacting society and increasing opportunities and risks. We provide a quick reference summary of CDBCs’ evolving landscape by comparing the Digital Pound, Digital Euro, and Digital Yuan, and point out some of their most relevant open issues, with insights into motivations, design considerations, and potential impacts of these major CBDC initiatives.

articles.title: Introduction to PQ Workshop
SQIsign The new herald of isogeny based crypto
articles.abstract: We present SQIsign, a digital signature scheme whose security is based on the presumed hardness of finding isogenies between supersingular elliptic curves.

articles.title: No one should learn from these errors: surveying fault attack resistance of post quantum cryptosystems
articles.abstract: Post-quantum cryptosystems are typically designed starting from instances of either public key encryption algorithms or hard problem instances, encasing them in widely recognized cryptographic constructions, which in turn are shared among the majority of proposals and create common targets for fault attacks, but also opportunities for overarching countermeasures. In this talk, we survey the fault resilience of these recurring structures in both Key Encapsulation Methods (KEMs) and signature schemes, taking as case studies both the current KEMs selected for the fourth round in the US NIST standardization process, and its on-ramp for post-quantum signatures.

articles.title: MCE and MEDS: From Group Actions to Signatures
Signatures from Five-Pass Zero-Knowledge Protocols and the Curious Case of CROSS
articles.abstract: Five-pass Zero Knowledge (ZK) identification protocols are a special type of ZK proof in which the prover and the verifier exchange, in each round, exactly five messages. In this talk we recall some of their properties, as well as guidelines to turn them into secure signature schemes. As a case study we consider CROSS, a scheme which has been submitted to the NIST call for additional signatures, which is based on the so-called Restricted Syndrome Decoding Problem (R-SDP).

articles.title: Introduction to TAC Workshop
Royal Rumbles in Cryptography: the NIST PQC Competition
The Zencode Whitepaper
Multiparty Class Group Encryption and Applications to E-Voting
Vote App: Verifiable and Coercion-Resistant I-Voting
articles.abstract: We present Vote App: an i-voting application which allows to participate in an election from anywhere. We will describe the cryptography behind the application and give some insights on the implementation challenges. Subsequently, we will stage a demo with a specially-tailored election where some volunteers will be able to cast their preferences.

articles.title: OpenABE Bindings for Kotlin
articles.abstract: We propose a wrapper consisting of bindings allowing to eas- ily use the OpenABE library — which provides several Ciphertext-Policy Attribute-based Encryption (CP-ABE) primitives — from any program written in the Kotlin language, which we choose for its popularity and multiplatform capabilities.

articles.title: Cryptographic Enforcement of  Attribute-based Access Control Policies
articles.abstract: We propose the implementation of a Cryptographic Access Control (CAC) scheme based on ABE for Cloud-Edge-Internet of Things (IoT) applications providing end-to-end protection of sensitive data against while enforcing dynamic and fine-grained Attribute-based Access Control (ABAC) policies.

articles.title: Privacy Preserving Machine Learning with TFHE
PPML: Machine learning on data you cannot see
Introduction to Group-based  Workshop
The Impact of the Semidirect Discrete Logarithm Problem (SDLP) in Post-quantum Cryptography PQC
Some results on the groups generated by round functions
articles.abstract: We present some results that characterize the properties of the permutation group generated by the round functions of a block cipher which guarantee security against known algebraic attacks.

articles.title: A method to cryptanalyze (Simultaneous) Conjugacy Search Problem in certain Metabelian Platform Groups
articles.abstract: There are many group-based cryptosystems in which the security relies on the difficulty of solving Conjugacy Search Problem (CSP) and Simultaneous Conjugacy Search Problem (SCSP) in their underlying platform groups. In this talk I will give a cryptanalysis of these systems which use certain semidirect product of abelian groups.

articles.title: Linearization of hard problems via right-angled Artin groups
articles.abstract: In this talk we will show how the natural bridge between graphs and right-angled Artin groups, and the multiplicative structure of the cohomology algebra of these groups, permits to translate hard graph-theoretic problems to the language of groups, in first instance, and then to linear algebra. This approach is very promising from the point of view of group-based cryptography.

articles.title: A “smart” application of homomorphic encryption
articles.abstract: We present a protocol based on Torus Fully Homomorphic Encryption for the aggregation of sensitive data.
